THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED .
LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.5oo,ooo
Paid up '' £ 5oo,ooo
Reserve Fund... 5oo,ooo
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.
Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231 1/2 per annum, P.T. 116 for (six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136k (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commance from the 1st or 16th of any month ADVERTISEMENTS.- P.T. 4 per line Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices In news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements. SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria. London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C. THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Mesars. May & Williams, 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED IN PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co. LIMITED (SALES OFFICE : 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880 Editor & Manager : R. Snelling Price: One Plastre Tariff.
SATURDAY, AUGUST 12, 1905.
THE PROSPECTS OF PEACE. We cannot say that the latest news from the United States gives any sore hope oi peace. M. de Witte has reiterated, time oat of mind, that Russia will pay no war indemnity, and even though the tribute levied oo the vanquiahed be styled "a reimbursement for war expenses”—an expression we oan cordially recommend to future conqueror*—we doubt whether all the gilding in the world will make Russia swallow the pilL The long delay sinoe the victory of Mokdan has onoe more given the Russians time to reorganise their foroes and fill op their gaps, and though Qeneral Iinievitch does not bear the reputation of a great strategist, and refugees from the scene of action tell stories of demoralisation and incipient matiny among his soldiers, still, it must be remembered that similar tales have been spread abroad sinoe Liao Yang, and that, in spite of them all, the Russian armies have never been routed, in the tense ol being not only defeated, bat demoralised for a considerable period after their defeat ; that, with the ooe exoeption of Port Arthur, avoidable surrenders on a large soale have been unknown; and that the Russian soldier, in spite of his iacompetent officers and imperfect training, always fights stubbornly, and retreats with regret The viotory of Tsushima has saved Japan from all risk at defeat and has assured Liautong, Korea Md Bsfbalien to her soldiers, bat the Russian armies may fight a retreating battle, draw away to Lake Baikal or the Upper Amor valley, and, maintaining half a million man there, weary the Japeoese, who will be obliged to tutataio an approximately qual force in Manchuria, into a oompromiao. In the ahock of battle the Japanese are perhaps invincible, but will even the heroes of the Shaho, Mukden, and Port Arthur prove themselves human after another two years of indecisive war t In the itixUsnth c-tntury one of the ablest of Asiatics, Toyotomi Hideyoahi, the Taiko-sama, or Great Lord, as the worshipper* at the shrine of his soul call him, led Japan to a five years' war of oinqueet in Korea against the Chinese and Koreans, whioh ended in the failure of all his plans, not so much through iU-euooess, as through the bitter home-sickness which is one of the prioea a patriotic army has to pay for a long campaign across the seas. Our soldier* undoubtedly grew homaiiok and ‘stale’ in South Africa, and it will be atrange if even the mo*t ardent Japaneee soldier ha* not aome of the edge taken ofi hi* martial temper *fter more rainy aummen and icy winter.- in the Manchurian plains. AU will depend, in our opinion, on the ability of Russia to play a long, slow, and unattractive game, without hope of any real victory—for the prisee of the.war must be to the Japaneee—but simply and solely with a view to making the peaoe terms leu onerous. And we submit that on this point the Russians themselves are the only possible judges. Were the revolutionary party in Russia led by oapable men, a long war might lead to the tall of the Tsardom, bat the earning cruise of the Potemkin, the failure of the striker* at Odessa to do more than provoke a nmnere, and the fact that a large section of the Russian people •teem* oontented with the promite* of relorm solemnly affirmed by the Tsar, makes u< inclined to suspect that the Tsar’e government will take the risk* of revolution. Bat a long struggle in the Bast must still further weaken Russian infiuenoe and prestige in the West, and from this obvious decline of her infiuenoe and prestige, mast be born the inducements to make peaoe quickly with the Japaneee. The mast pro-Gercn«a Russian cannot but feel dismayed at tho growth of German influence in theNearEi*t,theadvooato of expansion in the Middle Bast must feel alarm at tho rapid extension of British infiuenoe in the Persian Gulf; and it must be a galling reflection that Russia oau have now no say in Scandinavian politics, and oannot offer France more than platonio support in Moroooo. Thirty years ago Russia might perhaps have abandoned western politios and striven for years to minimise defeat in theEtst,but events move rapidly now-a-days, and Russia’s effaoe meat as a European power for a few years may prove a terrible handicap to her for another generation.
